Simplesmente um dos melhores filmes que já vi. Roteiro fantástico e criativo e as interpretações maravilhosas de Jim Carrey (esse que monstra um lado mais dramático ao contrário da maioria de seus personagens) e de Kate Wislet.

Having split with his girlfriend Joel discovers that she has had the memory of their relationship removed. In desperation he gets in contact with the inventor of the technology in order to have his own memories removed and help him move on.

A love story told in reverse Eternal Sunshine is a clever and touching movie that’ll really make audiences think about the nature of relationships and it’s all anchored by excellent performances from Jim Carrey and, the always reliable, Kate Winslet. Recommended.

mixed.review: This is a really weird movie. I had to watch it about 3 or 4 times before you really figure it out. It's a good concept but a bit confusing sometimes.

Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind. And you try to remember me. It's a very weird and boring movie. I liked only the moments when various things or people disappeared, and the rest is not even interesting to watch.

I've heard so much about this movie and I think watching it 15 times after it got released did hurt a little the movie overall score. The acting is very good, especially by Jim Carrey standards but I think that Clementine, Kate Winslet character is played over the top. My biggest problem with this movie is the pacing and the order that the script is played, the scenes where the main protagonists are together are very good but when it comes to the secondary characters they don`t feel as important to the plot. They feel like exposition characters just to set the plot in motion. I feel that the soundtrack is also lacking especially not a single licensed track is memorable and in a romance movie that is a really important part of your movie. Overall this isn`t a BAD movie perse but, I think that this movie lacks in the areas that romance movies should really work, Jim Carrey and Kate Winslet do have chemistry but a convoluted narrative ruined the movie for me.

Usually we're used to think of Jim Carrey as a comedy actor but in this film he shows that he's capable of dramatic roles, as he had done in "Truman Show". In this film, he tries to forget a failed romance with the irreverent Clementine (Kate Winslet) through a procedure that is, in practice, a brainwashing. But he regrets that with the process ongoing and tries to find a way to keep his memories. The film seems quite original and, in fact, the script has merit for trying to create a romantic comedy on a premise so different from the normal, but a large part of the plot is highly predictable. Another problem was the dialogues. In a film so light and so romance-oriented why insist on profanity or heavy slang? Some special effects look good, in particular the fading things and the passages from one memory to another at random, allowing us to have a wider knowledge of Joel's past. The soundtrack is quite kitsch and match the taste of both main characters but displeases the ears of the audience. Carrey was perfect in the main character, maintaining a good chemistry with Winslet, who also didn't disappoint. The rest of the cast (where we can see Elijah Wood, Kirsten Dunst or Tom Wilkinson) do their job satisfactorily, but leaving room for the main actors to shine.

negative.review: I like stories about memory manipulation, but the movie itself is B O R I N G. The concept is good but everything built around it is not.

featured-review.tagline: Incredible, moving movie.
featured-review.review: A lot of things have been said about this fantastic movie, and I only hope to add a few more praises.The fact that it was written by Ben and Matt was a shock to me, I did not expect any strong writing and a solid script, but boy was I wrong. The movie lasts for 2 hours, and every minute of it I couldn't even focus on anything beside the incredible world of Will Hunting.Matt plays Will Hunting, who is a brilliant young man who denies his unreal intellect. Will has had a very abusive childhood which hurt him mentally to a point where he can no longer let anyone close to him aside from his best friend who is played by Ben. That is until a professor at one of the top colleges finds Will's talent and helps him out of trouble with the law. Robin Williams later comes in as a therapist to Will, he is the only one who can really stand up to Will's intellect and manages to break the layer of distrust that Will has developed over years of solitude, and the two develop a bond beyond friendship.Yes there is a girl, but this is not a romantic movie. There is more to life then what we are taught and what we have to show for it.The writing is witty, brilliant and hilarious at times, both Matt and Robin Williams preform wonderfully from both a comedic and theatrical prospective. Matt's best work since Dogma and Williams best along side Dead Poet's Society.If your looking for a typical Hollywood movie with a Hollywood ending, then do not bother spending two hours on this movie. This movie is ahead of it's time, and lands an easy 10 out of 10.This one is a keeper in my movie library.

positive.review: Intimate, heartfelt and wickedly funny, it's a movie whose impact lingers.
First and foremost, Good Will Hunting is a film riding young, exuberant energies.
With its sweet soul and sharp mind, it's one of the most heartening films of the year.
The script's bare bones are familiar, yet the film also has fine acting, steady momentum, a sharp eye and a very warm heart.

Director Van Sant, who made the lyrical "Mala Noche," "Drugstore Cowboy" and "My Own Private Idaho," returns to his favorite hunting ground -- the subworlds of grimy, poetic lost boys -- and pulls us right in
Intelligently written, sharply directed, and beautifully played.
Damon convincingly matches Williams recrimination for recrimination in this portrayal of mutual tough love, even with the latter giving what may be the best performance of his career.
Gus Van Sant, working from the tangy, well-written script, gets so much humor, grit and emotional truth out of this tale that the familiar formulas behind it simply fall away.
This beautifully realized tale is always engaging and often quite touching.
The script also happens to be quite literate and laceratingly funny, and Damon -- no big surprise here -- turns out to be the perfect actor to deliver Will's zingers.
Fairly bursts with the exuberance and youthful energy that must have attended its creation.
It's the individual moments, not the payoff, that make it so effective.

An ordinary story told well. Taken as a whole, there's little that's special about this tale -- it follows a traditional narrative path, leaves the audience with a warm, fuzzy feeling, and never really challenges or surprises us.
You'd never guess this just-off-center movie was directed by indie hero Gus Van Sant. Maybe, like Will, he's casual about his gifts and feels no need to trot them out.

Presents a few too many hugs and arguments over what's best for Will. But ultimately, the movie, like its protagonist, boasts an integrity and intelligence that are tough not to admire. [25 December 1997, Tempo, p.1]
Stuffed--indeed, overstuffed--with heart, soul, audacity, and blarney. You may not believe a minute of it, but you don't necessarily want to stop watching.
Both smart and shrewd -- it wraps that same comforting message in a thoroughly entertaining package.
Damon benefits greatly from a director like Gus Van Sant ("My Own Private Idaho") who understands quiet, funny moments, intricate relationships and beautiful young actors.
Thanks to solid performances by Damon, Williams, and Driver, the story glides by on charm.
While the charismatic performances of Damon and Affleck make Good Will Hunting a difficult entertainment to resist, doing just that is not as hard as the film would like to think.
This is good, solid work that never achieves either the art or poignance of Van Sant's earlier and more personal projects.

It isn't surprising that the film was originally based on actors' improvisations, since it creates a universe of tremendously enjoyable characters and allows them plenty of room to roam, but has only the most predictable notion of plot and nothing whatever to say beyond be-yourself pieties.
Part character study, part redemptive drama, and all cheesy heart, it's Boston-baked melodrama, a little too gooey at times, but still pretty delicious.

mixed.review: Matt Damon and Robin Williams give touching performances, but Gus Van Sant's filmmaking is surprisingly ordinary.

Hearts sinking, we are obliged to endure much pseudo-serious gabble as we head toward another painfully predictable triumph of the human spirit. There must be some better way of hunting our--and Oscar's--goodwill. [Dec. 1,1997]
Van Sant's direction is surprisingly static and conventional, which doesn't help this earnest, underwhelming misfire.
Damon--as actor, not as co-screenwriter--is the best thing about Good Will Hunting.
The acting is top-notch and some scenes are authentically well-observed.

positive.review: This movie is the only movie that deserves a ten. This movie has a big meaning, psychologist debunk this movie and, the character will is "acting" realistically. A defensive, abused both mentally, and physically born in a bad family, meets Sean to avoid jail time. The interaction between them is magnificent. Robin Williams is the best actor in the world.

I've got to hand it over to Matt & Co. for nothing short of a phenomenal movie which conveys a really deep message. Will's journey of letting himself open as he changed from that bold kid hiding behind his insecurities to the man who regained the true meaning of his life. The cast is nothing short of spectacular and is pretty touching. There are quite a few "mistakes" Will made but that's what makes this movie so good, it's humanity. It's not an elaborate exaggerated Hollywood story but the story of one's self-discovery. I really love how the ending sorts it all out and the bonding between Will and Sean really reaches out to the viewers.

Psychological drama well in the beginning of Ben Aflleck and Matt Damon in their careers - they star (with Matt in the role of the protagonist) and wrote the script together. The director was Gus Van Sant (Drugstore **** movie tells a story about a irish-descendant boy in Boston that works as janitor in a mathematics faculty, and it is a self-taught genius, with a troubled past and present - some  mathematical riddles are left by the head of the chair in the faculty (Skarsgård) and mysteriously solved by night. Catching up with Matt Damon character Will he can be out of parole if he gets a job and consult with a psychiatrist what shows to be a tid bit tough thing. The film received positive reviews from critics and grossed over $225 million during its theatrical run against a $10 million budget, and received nominations in nine categories, including Best Picture and Best Director, and won in two: Best Supporting Actor for Williams and Best Original Screenplay for Affleck and Damon. Nothing bad, at all for someone being just out of Harvard University. Anther curiosity: character Skylar in the movie have the same name and background of Matt Damon's girlfriend back then.Robin Williams acts as the psychiatrist that could connect with this troubled boy, in a solid role - speaking of solid role it was nice to see Matt Damon out of some action movie in really nice drama scenes. Another actor that shows up is Stellan Skarsgård, yes the father of the four sons the most known being Bill (of "It"). Nice heartwarming moving movie thought the end with a solid script. I would scorre it a 8.0 out of 10.0 / B+. It is strange that I didn't even reminded this one back in 97, but then I remembered that that year I was in the 3rd year of Medicine so not much time to seeing movies I guess.

Both aesthetically and emotionally inspiring, Will Hunting’s psychological endeavor or ‘hunt’ for self-determination and a struggle to form relationships are reflected through Matt Damon’s visible agony. The plot is anything but thick as it questions the definition of success as argued by Lambeau and Chuck, and eventually answered by Will in his own way. A characteristically “feel-good” movie with an expected “happy” ending is complimented by the excellent portrayal of the characters.

A deeply human and beautiful examination of how compassion and humanity help us cope with the effects of trauma and abuse. Matt Damon gives a beautifully vulnerable performance, with Robin Williams rising to meet him in every scene they share. All the other actors in the movie, including Ben Affleck and Minnie Driver, play their parts wonderfully.

It also cannot be denied that this is a compelling and wonderfully written screenplay, which has received many deserved accolades since the movie's release. The aforementioned excellent acting from everyone involved helps this movie to ascend beyond the sum of its parts, placing it deservedly among many other classic movies of the 20th century.

Good Will Hunting is poignant, realistic and beautiful, and will likely appeal to a number of different individuals, who will almost certainly be able to relate to the raw  and real relationship between Damn and Williams.
I think, definitively, this is the best Damon has ever been, the rest of the cast is fantastic and works really well together.

Why it rocks: Will is a troubled person, but he’s really a good guy and never feels like he’s troubled just for the sake of being troubled. There are also some laughs and I love how there are plenty of topics that men refuse to talk about. The acting is great, the plot is simple and nothing really falls apart.
Intelligently written, Good Will Hunting is, in my opinion, a cult of the history of cinema with some brilliant ideas and others less interesting.

Me fez refletir sobre o futuro, sobre como ser jovem significa um futuro onde tudo pode ser possível. Me fez lembrar de como impomos limites ao nosso potencial, por conta de medos em nosso passado. Me fez pensar em como muitas vezes vivemos sob a expectativa de outros, porque nós mesmos não temos sonhos e aspirações. Com tudo isso dito, ainda sobram atuações brilhantes e diálogos excelentes. Muito comovente.

Good Will Hunting is a wonderful drama about the talented young mathematician Will. A superb cast, surprisingly it's one of Matt Damon's best acting works. And of course, a wonderful game by Robin Williams. A Good Will Hunting drama that exists and will exist beyond time, it will always be relevant. Good Will Hunting is a prime example of demonstrating people's self-reflection. Throughout the film, 2 societies are opposed: the intelligentsia societies led by Gerald Lambeau and the societies of ordinary friends with Chuck. The finale of Good Will Hunting is excellent, Will chose love after all, which only happens 1 time

One of my favorite all time movies.  Relatable and likable characters, addresses common conflicts like: what is expected vs what you want, ambition vs safety, and avoiding real connections vs risking being hurt.

Personally, my favorite movie of all time. I first time watched this movie back in 2009 on Netflix and I was captivated by Matt Damons character as well as Robbin Williams. This is a movie is littered with valuable life lessons and never act hot-headed or arrogant. It's a movie that teaches humility and I was so moved by it. The acting was phenomenal, great cinematography, and absolutely great writing. An absolute A+!

I don't think I have been this moved by a movie in a while. Good Will Hunting is an incredible movie and if I had to say what I think is Gus Van Sant's best film, this would be it. It is a slow-burner, but I think this was purposefully done and it added to the film's poignancy and psychological aspect.

Good Will Hunting is a beautifully filmed movie with striking scenery, and it is directed wonderfully by Van Sant. The music is never obtrusive but never too low-key either, while the story is interesting and compelling and the script intelligently written.

The acting is one of the film's best assets, as well as its compellingly real characters. Robin Williams is superb in one of his best "drama" roles, while Ben Affleck has never been better and Matt Damon gives another fine performance to match his performance in The Talented Mr Ripley. Minnie Driver is also quite touching and believable.

All in all, an incredible movie. 10/10 Bethany Cox

Good Will Hunting: Now I said I couldn’t review this movie because I wouldn’t be doing it justice but I’m only doing it because of the brilliant Robin Williams, Rest In Peace to a actor we lost too soon. So yeah this movie is another one that everyone should see because the way Matt Damon and Ben Affleck this art is that they fake you out in the beginning making you think it’a a comedy but then you get introduced to Robin’s character and then the movie flips into a drama. So the main person I really want to bring light on is Robin because he is so amazing in this roll he goes from being a humble person to grabbing Matt’s character by the neck and that’s what makes him feel more real, he has emotions and with his perfect performance he brings weight to a certain type of character and I don’t think I can ever unsee the way he plays him and I don’t want to either. Overall watch it. Ranking: Masterpiece.
Matt Damon i Ben Afflack stworzyli kapitalny scenariusz. Należy pamiętać również o roli Robina Williamsa za którą dostał oscara.

Damon and Williams do an excellent job I think it is the best acting job of Damon's career.  A movie that anyone of any age can draw some likenesses to the main characters.  Do yourself a favor watch this movie.

"It's not your fault" scene was definitely the saddest scene in this movie. I liked also how this movie shows a chemistry in a friendship between Matt Damon and Ben Affleck as they make you believe that they are not acting at all. Also as someone who also has trouble to find myself in something to be happy, I can relate to this movie so much. Definitely one of the rare movies that had me cry so much.

Good Will Hunting is a charming movie driven by a brilliant script (co-written by Ben Affleck and Matt Damon) and stellar performances, in particular from Damon (the best of his career in my opinion) and the late Robin Williams.
This is honestly one of the best films I have ever seen considering the year it was made great actors, amazing plot, truly incredible

'Good Will Hunting' is a drama that earned $225 million, whereas the budget of the movie is $10 million. It was directed by Gus Van Sant in 1997.

The movie is about a twenty-year-old genius and the influence of his difficult childhood on his life.

The high-level acting and well-written script attract moviegoers all over the world. The script was written by Ben Affleck and Matt Damon. 'Good Will Hunting' won two Academy Awards: the Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay and the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor.

Written by Anastasiia Shystovska

Good Will Hunting is such a brilliant movie and it's especially a masterpiece and a half. The movie's got such an amazing story and it's about this lad who's called Will Hunting (Matt Damon), who's this very intelligent genius at mathematics and he's really good at solving all the difficult mathematical problems.

However, when he starts to face an emotional crisis, he starts to see many different psychiatrist's until he finds the right one who can help him and his name is Dr Sean Maguireto (Robin Williams), who later helps Will recover.

The movie's got some amazing performance's from all of the cast, especially from Will (Matt Damon) and Sean (Robin Williams), those two are honestly brilliant and the two of them bring their characters to life so well.

The dialogue which is given and received from each character throughout this movie is all very strong dialogue. The dialogue which this movie's got never feels weak at any moment and every single bit of the dialogue comes out very strong.

The movie's cinematographer Jean-Yves Esoffier does such a beautiful job on capturing each moment and each emotion from each character so beautifully, he honestly does it so well.

Also, the chemistry between Matt Damon and Robin Williams throughout this movie is honestly great and it adds so much to their friendship in this movie and it works perfectly.

The pacing in this movie is honestly great, each main moment which ends up happening throughout this movie is all well built up and it's so beautifully well done.

The movie's even got some brilliant humour, which is well scattered throughout and all of the humour works very well in making me laugh in some sort of way.

Finally, the movie's got some really great emotions and they're all well built up with the great pacing and it really adds to their characters as a whole throughout this movie.

The movie's even got some brilliant character development with the main character Will, It's so beautifully well done and it works so perfectly due to the events, which end up happening to him.

The love interest in this movie, which is between Will and Skylar (Minnie Driver) is so beautifully well done and the certain events, which end up happening throughout their relationship are all well built up.

Overall, Good Will Hunting is such a brilliant movie with such an amazing story, amazing performances, very strong dialogue, beautiful cinematography, great chemistry, great pacing, brilliant humour, great emotions, brilliant character development and such a beautiful love interest.

I'd honestly recommend Good Will Hunting, if you're wanting to watch a very beautiful Drama/Romance movie. It's honestly worth the watch, it's so amazing.

Fantastic film. Great, very reflective story and amazing direction by Gus Van Sant. Robin Williams, Matt Damon, Ben Affleck andStellen Skarsgard's performances are exceptional. All of the characters are relate-able, the story makes you think about your own life in reflection.

This movie is nothing but a masterpiece. The characters all have so much depth, and the actors all pull them off beautifully. The writing was genius, especially for Damon and Affleck having been so young at the time. The only downside now is Harvey Weinstein's involvement, but there's no changing that now.

Accept Your Blessings.

Good Will Hunting

Van Sant's coaching is pretty much what you already know. His guidance isn't extraordinary but is undeniably productive. This vivacious film runs on nothing but the merit of the script. Matt Damon and Ben Affleck, the writers, aren't bringing anything new on the table, but it is the Disney of the dramatic movies. Incredibly confident in its ingredients, the film never stutters, not even for a frame. What's been so crowd pleasing about the script, is its ability to create a topsy-turvy world in a pragmatic one. Usually, the concept of "power" in the hand is often presented as misused by the characters and also always is craved by them.

In here, Matt Damon who powerfully portrays a guy that accounts in, his photographic memory as a hindrance. His surrounding doesn't ask him to repel it, but his affection towards that very surrounding and the fear to go physically distant with it, makes him turn all this into a hobby. Damon's excruciating performance of an arrogant and blessed kid has a match that makes him rubble in a snap.

And the answer is Robin Williams, that cloaks in a completely opposite persona to Damon in order to get in, in his game. If Damon likes to hurt, he keeps his wound open, if Damon oozes power and rage, he whispers warmth so gently that it makes your eyes teary within a blink. And despite of all the other tracks sprinkled amazingly in the film, Williams and Damon sharing a few laughs sitting in the room is the best asset of it, that Gus Van Sant is well aware of and encourages it like some big antic to stand tall and proud upon. Good Will Hunting is never a hunt, if anything it is the surrender in a long lasting lost game, that actually our host never cares for.
Touching and relfexive. A few films talks about wasted talent. One of the best and emotional Matt Damon's acting.

While the plot is quite generic and predictable, where the film and script truly shines is in the little moments of hooliganism it captures. A light-hearted film about redemption and forgiveness that almost makes me hate calculus a little less. Almost.
Brilliant performances and good message about self growth and realising your potential

What it is to be enveloped by ignorance for your own self, not knowing what you want and what you do with your life? Even people with talents are not insured against this possible daily burden. The greatest pain is to live, going downstream. But hugging life, we should not lose the much needed faith. There is something good there, in the future, hiding and waiting. Waiting for us, who, in the meantime, are on the spiral of time. Getting closer.

A movie about the need for self-knowledge. About the turns of life. About love.
HOW is this movie only an 8.9? A brilliant movie. A work of art. A must-see!

This is honestly a brilliant movie, with two big-shot Hollywood actors, Matt Damon and the late Robin Williams. It is about a extremely intelligent person who is only a Janitor, and after he is jailed for assaulting someone he has to go and see a therapist. I'll let you watch the movie, but the rest of it is about him uncovering his potential making friends and learning valuable lessons. Highly Recommended.

Sharp and heart touching story **** in development, mixed in character with an angry man. Pay attention of rookies Matt Damon and Ben Affleck; Robin Williams is also remarkable in the role of psychologist.

Good Will Hunting is a modern day classic about finding one's place in the world, and conquering your fears. A touching, inspirational film with a great script, great performances (Matt Damon, Robin Williams, and Ben Affleck really shine) and good cinematography. Good Will Hunting is guaranteed to uplift anyone who watches it.

Damon, Affleck, Skarsgard, and Williams all give fantastic performances, but that isn't what makes this film special. What makes this a classic is the writing by Matt Damon and Ben Affleck. They make the characters seem real, and makes the viewer invested in them.
A definitive classic without a doubt. With a a powerful screenplay, outstanding acting performances and a touching story, Good Will Hunting is a powerful movie that anyone should enjoy.
Great movie annnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnddddddddddddddddddddddddddddddddddddddddddddddddddddddddddd yeaaaaaaaaaaaahhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhh

Nothing less than a masterpiece and written by Matt Damon and Ben Affleck at such young ages. The writing is brilliantly heartfelt and funny, the acting is brilliant and the whole feeling of the film is beautiful. Honestly my favourite film ever.

Good Will Hunting is an incredible film about growing up and believing in yourself. Its got a lot of great lessons and would be a great watch for adolescents. Great writing, great casting, great performances, and a large emotional impact all help the movie to be truly special.

The magical feeling you get by watching "Good Will Hunting" will make you question the meaning to filmmaking and life as a whole. When Sean Maquire (Robin Williams) states "you'll have bad times, but it'll always wake you up to the good stuff you weren't paying attention to" leads me to think of the negative moments in my life that inspired me to be a big-time movie fan. Good Will Hunting will express the deepest emotions your mind can possibly experiences by bringing you tears, laughter and even anger.

It's over-long for a film of its nature, but despite the length, the film does not lag. In fact, it is beautifully filmed, exceptionally acted, brilliantly written, and---in the end---extremely heartwarming. It is a triumph.

Good Will Hunting is one of the greatest American Movies of all time. It is both Robin Williams and Matt Damon's best performances, and Robin Williams won the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor. Good Will Hunting is both wise and deep. It really makes you stop and look at yourself and life.
A compelling, funny, and ultimately moving examination of life's priorities, with mesmerising performances from Damon, Affleck and the late Robin Williams.
Let's be honest. Everybody at one point in hist life wants to be that smart boy in the bar who teaches a lesson to that **** **** who is picking on his friend.
This is a really good movie. The plot and the characters are really interesting and make for a great watch. Matt Damon and Ben Affleck do a great job.

mixed.review: I've always found this movie a little bit overrated since it is an ordinary movie with an ordinary screenplay directed by a great director that here only manages to make his work without giving the passion he gave in his previous films. That's what I feel as a viewer.

The film has good intentions and ideas where they are best depicted in amazing scenes involving Matt Damon as the titular character and Robin Williams as professor Sean McGuire (in his best dramatic role). Their chemistry is very strong and the ideas and values they talk about are both fascinating and engaging. I wish that this whole film's plot could've just solely been about these two, but disappointingly, the screenplay written by Matt Damon and Ben Affleck is too incompetent (it's a good thing they stuck to acting I suppose). In between the thought-provoking scenes involving Damon and Williams is a cliché-ridden story told with characters that are not engaging nor have enough backstory for us, the audience, to care about. All I need to say is that it is a romance plot with the titular character and a girl and there's a misunderstood fight between them ****....yeah. It's that same old 'song and dance' we all achingly know. In fact, the effect the film had on me was a tug-of-war, pulling me back and forth between smart characters with smart dialogue and dumb characters with dumb dialogue. I'm teetering on the fence for "Good Will Hunting". I want to like this film, but I just can't stomach its amateur plot peppered with intelligent scenes. It (sadly) comes across as Hollywood trying to relate with the smart crowd and failing, which in turn, makes for a phony film.

Good Will Hunting keeps you engaged by its incredible performances from Robin Williams and Matt Damon, but it's conventional plot and unoriginal love scenes hinder the film from being anything special.

Unoriginal and slow. It's easy to tell how the film is going to end and how events are going to play out within the first 10 minutes of watching. The film  unrealistically portrays mathematics as being something easy to grasp for someone with such a high intellect. No "super genius" can solve complex math problems the way Will does. Matt Damon's and Robin William's performances are exceptional.

negative.review:
Alright, I am going to go straight ahead and say that in no way do I understand how people manage to like this movie.

Absolutely everything in this film is outright terrible: the premise of two grown men going out of their way to help some guy "because he's a genius", the cliché boring love interest and friend subplots, young Damon showing his "intellect" by citing old books with a super-serious face, Affleck picking up girls (extra cringy!), Williams remembering his wife's farts (literally), Minnie Driver's story about geriatric blowjobs, Casey Affleck jerking off (not shown explicitly, thankfully), the battered "do what you really like, don't miss your true love" morale... The list could go on forever, or for about two hours, to be exact.

The only bright spot is Robin Williams (when he's not remembering his wife's farts, obviously), his performance is solid, his smile heart- warming, his wrists very hairy.

What I also don't get is why people have doubts whether Affleck and Damon actually wrote this piece of trash. I mean come on, saying that someone isn't capable of even coming up with something as bad as Will Hunting is probably the worst insult there is.

featured-review.tagline: An Oscar well deserved.
featured-review.review: This film is one of a kind.  After seeing this film last week, I was left with a hole in the pit of my stomach.  It left many questions in my mind, and most of them cannot be answered. In my view, a film that makes me think after I watch it is second-to-none, and this film certainly delivers in that aspect.I was amazed with the vivid imagery in this movie, as well as with the symbolism.  However, what makes this film the best of 1999 is the acting. Kevin Spacey shines as Lester Burnham, and Annette Bening (Carolyn Burnham) isn't far behind.  Supporting cast members such as Wes Bentley (Ricky Fitts), Thora Birch (Jane Burnham), Mena Suvari (Angela Hayes), and Chris Cooper (Col. Frank Fitts) only add to the drama of this film.  I think the most special aspect of this film is how all of the characters intertwine in a way that is believable, yet fantastic at the same time.  I congratulate Sam Mendes for his direction of this film, as well as Alan Ball for writing it.  I don't think it could have been any better.Rated R in the U.S. for strong sexuality, language, drug content, and violence, the film obviously deserves its rating.  However, none of the causes for the R rating are overbearing, and all of them add to the plot-line of this film.  While I don't think that this is a film for children, I would suggest that adults should view it with an open mind.  I believe that the traits which many of the characters in this film have are found in many people around the world. Perhaps that is why this film hits close to home for so many viewers.While billed by some as a "comedy-drama", I don't see anything about this film as funny.  Sure, there are some comedic moments, but by the end, those moments were all but forgotten when faced with the grim reality of the conclusion of the events portrayed in this film.If you want to watch a light-hearted film with some elements of comedy and some elements of drama, don't see American Beauty.  But if you enjoy films that make you think, and are entertained by an excellent cast, excellent directing, and an excellent screenplay, this film should be at the top of your list.My Rating:  10/10

positive.review: Spacey, an actor who embodies intelligence in his eyes and voice, is the right choice for Lester Burnham.
A dark comical masterpiece that single-handedly announces the collapse of the American family infrastructure as it exists on the brink of Y2K.
It gracefully defies the usual categories, gets under your skin in ways you cannot anticipate, then works its way straight toward the heart.  It's far and away the bravest and best movie of the year.
A tart, funny and tremendously sobering movie about the deepest recesses of personal unhappiness.
Spacey is diamond-brilliant in a role that plays as if custom-made for him.
A wonder of a film -- a luminous, beautifully executed drama that gathers the best cast of the year -- the best American film of the year.
A dynamite comedy-drama that, unless it stiffs big-time at the box office, should be up for multi-Oscar nominations come February.
A flat-out masterpiece, surely the best movie of the year; indeed, an all-time classic.
A singular accomplishment so specifically keyed to Spacey's talents that it mandates going out on a limb to say it contains the performance that will ultimately be regarded as "the one."

A triumph of acting, writing and directing that defies glib description...the kind of artful defiance that Hollywood is usually too timid to deliver: a jolting comedy that makes you laugh till it hurts.
A movie that will endure.
Hilarious, slightly sick, and super-edgy ...the acting of its two principals, Annette Bening and Kevin Spacey, is so sublime that it's worth seeing on that grounds alone.
Hilarious, painful and brutally frank.
A script as fresh and distinctive as any produced in the States in recent memory.
If you don't share the film's piercing vision of what really matters, someday you will.
A blood-chilling dark comedy with unexpected moments of both fury and warmth, a strange, brooding and very accomplished film that sets us back on our heels from its opening frames.
A brilliant satirical diagnosis of what's most screwed up about life in this country, especially when it comes to sexual frustration and kiddie porn.
A brilliant, exhilarating piece of filmmaking.  It may even be the best mainstream film of the year thus far.
Remarkably astute and devastatingly funny.
(Mendes') film debut shows he can shock not only with noise and nakedness but with subtle observations.
I've got to admit it's a stunner.
Though excellent in many ways, American Beauty is, finally, an uneasy mix of assured technique and simplistic satire.
You know you're in the hands of a true filmmaker when you feel invited, at every turn, to share his sense of entrancement.  I got that feeling in just about every frame of American Beauty.
Kevin Spacey (gives) a truly great performance.
Surprises you with a kind of hardheaded romanticism.
Black comedy of the deepest, richest darkness laid over an aching meditation on the atrophy of dreams.
A ruthless dissection of suburban malaise.
Mendes nonetheless works this screenplay like a jazz virtuoso plays with a familiar theme such as "Mary Had a Little Lamb."

If it is never really as profound as it seems to think it is, American Beauty is consistently entertaining, and it earns points simply for acknowledging that all may not be perfect in the current boom years.
A satire whose dead aim stops wounding - and starts making - stereotypes of white middle-classness.

mixed.review: It remains a puzzling dream, vivid in detail and overly obvious in symbolism, fueled by half-digested lumps of malice and wonder.
Bland and nasty, American Beauty has the slightly stale feel of a family sitcom conceived under the spell of "Married . . . With Children."
In the end, the film lacks the skill of its actors and ends up feeling disjointed and confused about its own message.

negative.review: The deeper American Beauty tries to get, the shallower it reveals itself to be.

positive.review: A crafted movie with an excellent cast and a powerful story. It’s a film that will make you think and feel deeply about life, love, and the human condition.

I wasn't expecting to like American Beauty, but I did, loved it more like. The story mayn't be original at first glance, but how the film is written and constructed more than compensates you completely overlook. You may argue the characters are weird and unlikeable, maybe so, but they are quite complex. Lester is a self-described loser who is unwanted by everyone, Carolyn is uptight and sexually frustrated, Jane is the epitome of a sulky teenage daughter and Allison is like a incipient Lolita who Lester becomes smitten with. American Beauty is probably an example of a movie that you may need to see more than once to truly appreciate it, I was like that with Vertigo.

What I love about American Beauty is not only the complex characters, but also the stylish filming, haunting score, side-splitting scenarios, the intelligent and darkly funny screenplay and the assured direction from Sam Mendes. Not to mention the performances which are nothing less than impeccable, especially Kevin Spacey who thoroughly deserved his Best Actor Oscar. Annette Bening, Peter Gallagher, Thora Birch and Mena Suvari give wonderful support too. Quintessentially, American Beauty is just a wonderful, funny and brilliantly performed and directed film. 10/10 Bethany Cox

American Beauty. Not everyone will be able to understand and see the beauty. In a good way, a very unusual and at the same time ordinary film. The plot is quite simple, but the message of the film itself can be understood in many ways. The acting is great, the music is amazing, and the film itself sinks into the soul for a very long time.

American Beauty is an example of a very rare movie that will always be relevant. First of all, this is the best role of Kevin Spacey in his career, one of the most successful films of the filmmaker's debuts and the best film by Sam Mendes. A simple but very realistic story. Also a crazy ending. This film can be advised to everyone, it is suitable for any generation of people.

American Beauty is one of the most strangest and fascinating films I've ever seen. The film provides a satire about the middle class's perception of love and beauty, while delving deeper into the themes of love, sexuality, materialism and liberation and providing a character study about a man slowly delving deeper into his fantasies. Kevin Spacey does a great job in portraying Lester Burnham and he genuinely comes off as creepy. The cinematography is wonderful and Thomas Newman's score is phenomenal and compliments the story well. The biggest issue I have with the film is that the sex scenes are uncomfortable to watch and its depiction of sex comes off as disturbing and off putting. I never cared too much about the characters other than Lester and the film drags down during the second act. American Beauty can be a film that is hard to watch at times, but it does a great job in tackling its subject and it makes for a memorable watch.
A good movie but a bit stereotypical sometimes. A suburban neighborhood with interesting characters and an engaging story.

Sam Mendes domestic tale of secrets, mistrust and the desire for more is handled with intelligence and some clever dark humour.
A fine directorial debut.

Amazing movie. Great soundtrack, terrific acting, inspired plot, pleasant pace and rhythm. The characters are perfectly presented and linked to each other, which allows us to feel a certain empathy for each of them.

Originally released in 1999 'American Beauty' still shines by the topicality of the subjects it deals with. If it could have been called 'Beauty' only because it presents how human can evolve and elevate through time, it also has the decency and the presence of mind of adding the adjective 'American' to clearly insert itself in a socio-cultural tendency. The story shows multiple characters living in the 21st century in America with all its madness, its purity and fantasies. They all have to take a stand in order to be someone else rather than a poor stereotype or cliché. If in appearance people may seem almost normal we can always choose to live our lives in the way we want to. And when we choose to (re)take control of it the people around us may notice it. And react to it.

Some of the artistic choices may seem incomprehensible, such as the presence of rose petals here and there, which may give the impression that "American Beauty" is superficial or poorly thought out, but I think it brings a kind of lightness to the plot. I found myself disappointed by the end but I think it is the point: you can make effort to live closer than what you want but in the end reality always strikes back.
Greatly directed and written movie. Everyone should watch it once in a while and reflect on what's really important, our own happiness.
It’s the best movie of 1999 and it’s better than ever in my days as well

Tiene una buena historia y excelentes interpretaciones de un buen reparto de actores.
¡TOTALMENTE RECOMENDADA!

Director Sam Mendes brings us American Beauty... Made in 1999 but what the beauty of the film is is unclear. My only guess is Kevin Spacey looking at Mena Suvari in a cheerleading outfit because nothing much else makes sense. Anyway Kevin Spacey who plays Lester Burnham has a daughter played by the beautiful Thora Birch and he kind of ends up having a thing for her friend, Angela Hayes (Mena Suvari) which is the weirdest thing I've ever seen. The film is full of bits of nudity, perversion, sex scenes, Mena Suvari in a bath of red roses and Kevin Spacey being a jerk and creepy and sometimes funny but also drugs are involved. Great film in everyway from the great acting down to the beautifully shot red roses scenes and blah de blah. Mena Suvari is very beautiful and gives a good performance, Annette Benning is a bit boring but she doesn't ruin the film and Wes Bentley films Thora Birch from his window and Wes Bentley plays some weird next door neighbour with a **** dad who is convinced his son is having some **** relationship with Lester (Kevin Spacey) next door but he's not all there if you catch my drift. Some weird moments but beautifully executed film and a great movie.

Not the best film but I've seen many films much worser. American Beauty stars Kevin Spacey, Wes Bentley, Annette Benning, Thora Birch and Men's Suvari... American Beauty is an incredibly complex film that is able to convey deep themes about conformity, imprisonment, and life. What begins almost as a Comedy, full of laughable moment and, to be quite honest, some equally laughable dialogue slowly devolves into a tragedy in which the themes that Mendes is going for become apparent.

Kevin Spacey's character is the best acted of the film. Any scene he is in has him stealing the show. That being said the acting all around in this film is fantastic. Each character is written in such a way that aspects of them are likeable, but they all have tragic flaws. Perhaps they are angry at the world for existing, feel isolated by the families, or feel that the world revolves around them. The plot in general revolves around these flaws as they are exposed and concludes with all of the different threads converging together. The twists of that convergence is what truly makes this film remarkable.

The cinematography in American Beauty is also superb with some of the best that I have ever seen in a motion picture. The manner in which several scenes are shot (but especially one scene in particular) help contribute to essential themes that Mendes is trying to show.

Overall, American Beauty is a very unique film that I found to be through provoking throughout. The slow start that has one scene I found to be more cringy than either comedic or tragic is made up for the rest of the film, which is nothing short of a unique masterpiece.

Controversial, bold, with a touch of unpleasant brilliance ... but I confess I was expecting something else.

I confess I expected more from this movie. Considered one of the 100 best films ever by more than one list written by more than one authority on the subject, he has won five Academy Awards from the Hollywood Academy (Best Picture, Best Actor, Best Director, Best Original Screenplay, Best Photography) and three Globes of Gold (Best Picture, Best Director and Best Screenplay). It's an enviable record for a movie that, when we look at it, doesn't seem to justify it ... In fact, just looking at the Oscar nominees for Best Movie in that far 2000s, I liked "The Insider" or "a lot more" The Green Mile "than this movie, which basically portrays the unfulfilled fantasies of a middle-aged, suburban middle-class man when

In fact, the American middle class is portrayed here in an almost dystopian way: a social group wrapped in huge paranoia about appearances and "looking good," obsessed with politically correct and socially acceptable, trying to keep secrets, taboos, prejudices and imperfections hidden through a beautiful house, a spotless lawn, a new car, a good tie. The patriarch of the family lives a crisis of middle age through the nostalgia of past and underused youth, to the point of feeling a sudden sexual attraction for a teenager. His wife, in turn, is the archetype of frivolity and emptiness, living a marriage of appearances and discounting everything through an extramarital affair. The daughter of this dysfunctional couple is the typical young rebel ... until she decides to plot with her boyfriend to kill her own father. And there is much more throughout the movie. Cartoon characters in a dystopian and uncomfortable portrait, especially for those who identify with the US suburban middle class (not my case at all).

Kevin Spacey, Annette Bening and Thora Birch are the central trio of actors who bring life to a family that is beyond normal. Nevertheless, the three had excellent performances and in fact deserved to be awarded and recognized for that. Mena Suvari also looked good to me as the provocative nymphet. Sam Mendes ensured careful, bold and inspired driving. Having been the first film in which he participated as a director, it was certainly a milestone in his career and secured a future for him.

Provocative, bold, disturbing, is a movie where taboos are put in check and troublesome truths are exposed. It is not at all a family movie or to see with children and young people nearby.
Amazing movie. It's supposed to be sad but it's actually pretty funny. And it's very sad too.

When it comes to movies like other people and myself been thinking about, American Beauty is a film that really came to everybody's interests. People liked talking about it and recommending it to those who haven't seen it. I'm sure for the fact I've seen it and you know what? I love it to death. It's one of those movies that you have to watch before you die. It is one of my favourite films of all time. Kevin Spacey has done it again with his excellent performance like in The Usual Suspects. he won an Oscar for his performance as Lester Burnham and now he's a two time Oscar winner. Everyone else did a fantastic job acting in this film including Annette Bening. The story in this is great and flawless about Kevin Spacey as Lester Burnham narrating about his life. He has a wife, Carolyn Burnham played by Annette Bening who is an ambitious woman and a daughter, Jane played by Thora Birch who f**king despises her family. Wes Bentley as Ricky Fitts who is obsessively filming everything around his surroundings with his camcorder and he is curious about Lester's daughter, Jane next door. Lester hates his job, has a midlife crisis and becomes possessed with his daughter's best friend, Angela Hayes played by Mena Suvari. He starts having sexual fantasies about her, in which red rose petals are a recurring motif. As much as I love everything about American Beauty, this is something that I watch almost every night. It has that amazing impeccable cinematography that just makes the way the film looks satisfying like the red petals that Mena Suvari is laying on. That is the moment of beauty. "Spec-tacular!" The directing is really good. It's made by Sam Mendes who I assume who directs two James Bond movies like Skyfall and Spectre starring Daniel Craig. I was shocked by the fact that this was actually his first film which is quite a coincidance! I really, really love this film. It shows the characters how they're feeling and communicate with one another. Whenever you're think of American Beauty, you would be like, "Wow! That is the most beautiful film I've seen!" and it is a beautiful film with surprisingly dark humour, the acting is perfection, the story is well written, the cinematography is impeccably shot and it's definitely worth your five Oscars if you haven't seen it. This is one of Sam Mendes' incredible Oscar winning masterpieces! You have no idea what you're missing, I'm sure. But don't worry... you won't someday.

A film that I find absolutely perfect in any possible way. American Beauty is an all around magical film. It happens to be my favorite film of all time, and I don't see that changing anytime soon. It is a true study on characters, with one of the greatest screenplays ever written.

Fantastic movie about everything wrong in a household. A haunting tale of existential grief. First ten minutes you find a lame (and couldn't be more true to the word) dad whose wife drives him to work and acts a bit of a creep. A true way to take you on a philosophical journey as at the end you may start to realize that of all 10 or so characters maybe he was the most sane. Not a single character lives without flaws. You learn to love and hate almost everyone in this film and all the while it teaches you fundamental problems from all aspects of family.

Speechless!

I'm not kidding. I may not review this masterpiece because I really don't have anything to say about this flawless piece of art! But I'll see later, anyway.

God! That's why I hate perfect films.

(10/10)
An amazing and acerbic social criticism about the American way of life. It's truly shocking story but that reports many of the american's citizen hypocrisies. Genial as best.
Kevin Spacey in this role is absolutely phenomenal. This comedy-drama shows the true importance of living your life to the fullest and the consequences of your actions to others around you.

American Beauty:
A beautiful masterpiece that Hollywood is usually fearful of producing to the world.
Starring: Kevin Spacey. Annette Bening. Thora Birch.
Directed by Sam Mendes.
By Blake Patterson.
100/100.   “True realism consists in revealing the surprising things which habit keeps covered and prevents us from seeing,” said Jean Cocteau, a French writer. American Beauty, released in 1999, is a motion picture that can fool the public, if they just read the title. They would probably think that it is an idealistic movie about the beauty of America. Just to let the readers know, American Beauty is the complete opposite of romanticism. This film is a piece of realism that doesn't play safe. American Beauty is one of those rare all-time classics that radiates with an original plot, a first-rate cast, wicked provocation, and a fantastic crew; this critique will also include a personal experience.   As a consequence of pushing the envelope, American Beauty is a film doesn't play safe for its viewers. Alan Ball, the screenwriter of American Beauty, writes this film with such savage wit that it is so irresistible to watch. American Beauty is a morbid look into the lives of two dysfunctional families who are neighbors. People like to say that this film is about a sexually frustrated father who is obsessed with his daughter's sleazy friend. That is a subplot in this film, but that is not its focus. Professors are probably teaching this film to future screenwriters or anyone in the study of film. That's one of the reasons why American Beauty has such a fresh screenplay.   By the same token, American Beauty has an exceptional ensemble. Kevin Spacey portrays as the most blunt character, Lester Burnham, in the whole film, and he defines pure perfection in the role. Annette Bening is outstanding as Carolyn Burnham, Lester's wife. The young cast members, who are played by Thora Birch, Wes Bentley, and Mena Suvari, deliver awesome performances in the film. Viewers will witness other superb performances from Chris Cooper, Allison Janney, Peter Gallagher, etc. A masterpiece always includes a marvelous cast.   In addition to the following, American Beauty is one of the most provocative films ever made. One of the best parts of this film is how it conveys these characters with optimism, like I Love Lucy and other sitcoms, from the introduction. As the story furthers, it goes more in depth with these characters; this is a fine example of realism. People who want movies that show happiness should turn off the movie. Another reason why this film will trigger people is due to the eroticism displayed in this film; this will irritate prudish people. The other common reason why American Beauty is controversial is because of the mature themes it contains; the public will have to look closer, watch American Beauty, to discover what the subjects are. These are the common reasons why American Beauty causes attention.   In the meantime, I would like to discuss a personal experience that revolves around this film. Last year in Theater Arts 1, I chose to perform the introductory monologue from this film; by the way, the monologues in this film are well-written. I told my teacher about my choice for the project, and he was already supporting me. If I had told the other teacher in the auditorium about it, I wouldn't have been able to act it out due to one sexual reference. That shows how people are about content in movies these days.   As a result of brilliance, American Beauty includes ravishing work from the crew members. Audiences will experience gorgeous cinematography from Conrad L. Hall. They will also hear Thomas Newman's dazzling film score. American Beauty was Sam Mendes' debut as a director, and the stakes were high because of that. Mendes is an artist, and he knows how direct with enthusiasm. Kudos to the crew members for creating this film phenomenally.   In conclusion, American Beauty is one of the greatest films ever made. The film is flat-out uproarious, and then it gives audiences a compelling punch in the face. American Beauty won five Academy Awards including: Kevin Spacey for Best Leading Actor, Alan Ball for Best Original Screenplay, Sam Mendes for Best Director, Conrad L. Hall for Best Cinematography, and Best Picture. American Beauty is not only one of the best films of the nineties, but it is also one of the best movies of the twentieth century. Like Cocteau said in his quote above, American Beauty exhibits the surprises hidden in these humane characters, and it doesn't keep their secrets covered.

American Beauty is one of the best movies ever. It is so surreal and makes you think about life. Kevin Spacey has the best performance of his life, and Annette Bening also does a superb job. There is nothing wrong with this movie. 10/10 Stars, a must-see movie!
From it's acting performances, to it's beautiful cinematography, to it's controversial, yet interesting story, American Beauty is a near perfect film that truly makes you rethink about life.

Watching this film in the aftermath of Kevin Spacey's fall from grace, I expected to feel icky, and I did. However, this film is still incredible; it totally holds up. Annette Bening, Thora Birch, and ,yes, Kevin Spacey give incredible performances. Allan Ball's script a strange combination of deadpan humor and morose dialogue, but is somehow works.

The iconic movie of the pop culture! One of my top 5 favourite movies of all time, because of the intriging plot, beautiful soundtrack, mind-blowing simplicity of the visuals, and Kevin Spacey! That guy sure knows how to act! He deserved an Oscar! I'm glad that the movie won the Oscars for the best motion picture, and best Actor in the leading role, but i was dissapointed y the fact that the movie didn't for the best soundtrack!

At first it was a bit weird watching Kevin Spacey gawk at his teenage daughters best friend as I am watching this post-Spacey allegations however, the film really kicked off for me when that creepiness went away. The cast is absolutely sublime with Wes Bentley's enigmatic character a particular highlight and of course prime Spacey. It's darkly funny and utterly compelling with a belter of an ending. A classic and I feel it will be immensely rewatchable.

This film was amazing to watch. Its premise is beautiful, portraying mid-life crises as artistically as it can get. Led by the amazing Kevin Spacey, the performance of the whole is cast is just outstanding, and the plot shocked me, and had me in awe, at several points. This is definitely a film that deserves all the praise and the awards it received, for it is truly, as its title suggests, an american beauty. Totally a movie to see before you die!
The bittersweet, disenchanted portait of the american way of life in suburbia. Outstanding Kevin Spacey as the family guy in crisis looking for his second air. Smashing OST.

Is this the best film of the 90s? Quite possibly, as no other confuses and delights more than American Beauty. The subtle complexity of its original and brilliant screenplay, coupled with its sensitively fabricated representation makes for an outlook-altering experience. It doesn't matter how many times I watch American Beauty, I sense a new meaning each time and am never confident that I know what the film means or what it is trying to say. Of course, the enigmatic and darkly beautiful nature of the film is helped along by subtle, honest and terrific performances from Spacey and Bening, a mesmerising score and stunning direction, but underpinning this all is a witty, dark, optimistic, pessimistic, original and overwhelming screenplay that gives this film too many dimensions to wave matching gardening clogs at.

It's astounding that American Beauty was Sam Mendes's directorial debut; it is a film of awe and wonder, and is the kind of film you would expect from a seasoned director who knows how to incrporate complex themes and imagery into his/her movies. Nonetheless, it is an amazing picture about how not to judge a book by its cover, because the inside might be nasty and problematic. Its gorgeous cinematography, excellent acting, and superb direction earn its Best Picture Oscar.

An acerbic, darkly comic critique of how social conventions can lead people into false, sterile and emotionally stunted lives, "American Beauty" is a real American original.

The landscape of Ball’s story is the familiar one of small-town America, and the initial take on the subject is the equally familiar one of houses with white picket fences and perfectly manicured gardens providing deceptive facades for lives wracked by hostility, tension, noncommunication and perversity. Fortunately, this view is intended not as a revelation but as a given, a starting point for a subtle and acutely judged tale in which nearly every important character metamorphoses in an utterly unpredictable way.

Calmly observant narration by Lester Burnham (Kevin Spacey) informs at the outset that, in less than a year from the start of the story, he’ll be dead. “Of course, I don’t know that yet,” he quips as he and his family are trotted out. Lester is a self-described loser, having lost interest in his job at an advertising magazine as well as in any meaningful relationship with his beautiful, high-strung, real estate agent wife, Carolyn (Annette Bening), and sullen high school-age daughter, Jane (Thora Birch). Family life is a sham for all of them, and they deal with it in different ways: Lester admits it, Carolyn refuses to face it, and Jane is just waiting it out until she can fly the coop.

Threatened with dismissal from his job, hangdog Lester finds things begin changing for him when he becomes smitten by Jane’s best friend, Angela (Mena Suvari), a blond Lolita with sex on the brain. Exhilarated by the ludicrous prospect of seducing her, Lester begins obsessively pumping iron and fuels his youthful state of mind by smoking dope with a strange young man, Ricky Fitts (Wes Bentley), who has just moved into the house next door with his father (Chris Cooper), a recently retired Marine Corps colonel, and shut-down mother (Allison Janney).

Ricky frequently takes surreptitious video footage of Jane, and when she calls him on it, an unlikely but oddly convincing romantic friendship begins blossoming that finally gives Jane a release for her emotional frustration. Carolyn, for her part, seeks an outlet in the most conventional manner, lurching into a motel-room affair with the debonair “king” of local real estate, Buddy Kane (Peter Gallagher). Evidently the only well-adjusted and relatively happy people in the neighborhood are “Jim and Jim” (Scott Bakula and Sam Robards), a **** couple with whom Lester takes up jogging.

One of the film’s constant sources of delight and surprise is the way characters both hide and reveal their private interests, and how they are often perceived and misjudged by others. It is not giving away too much or going too far into the story’s many mysteries to say that Lester can approach serenity and even a state of grace despite his initial wormlike status; that Ricky confidently pursues a secret life in spite of close surveillance from his martinet father, who forces his son to submit to regular urine tests for drug use; that Carolyn’s materialist preoccupation has, in fact, become her substance, and that Jane’s amorphous personality is susceptible to being shaped in just about any direction by the first strong personality she meets.

Consistently provocative and devilishly amusing through the first hour, pic clicks into high gear midway when Lester and Carolyn finally have it out. They don’t declare war, exactly, but Lester decides to let down any pretense to responsibility or normalcy in order to do his own thing as he did when he was 20, carefree and full of expectation. Blackmailing his boss for a big severance package, he hilariously takes a gig at the job at which he was always happiest, flipping burgers at a fast-food restaurant, buys his dream car and openly smokes weed whenever he wants. His new freewheeling approach to life makes him giddy, so much so that he believes he and his wife can revive their long-buried sexual relationship. But Carolyn and Jane are appalled at his breezy, tell-it-like-it-is attitude, fomenting a mood of anxious melodrama leading to the event promised by the opening narration.

Mendes, the hottest young British theater director of recent years, on the basis of “Cabaret” and “The Blue Room,” displays a very sure hand in his first film. As precise and controlled in its effects as his legit work, “American Beauty” is stylized in its images and humor, and Mendes has been exceedingly fortunate in working with a cinematographer as skillful as vet Conrad L. Hall, who is unsurpassed in his ability to augment the meaning of the material he films by finding its perfect visual correlative.

Naomi Shohan’s production design and Julie Weiss’ costumes enhance the film’s look of designed reality, while Thomas Newman’s score and the many adroitly chosen song snippets often create ironic counterpoint to the exceptionally tart and entertaining proceedings.

Over the years, many films have taken a dark look at the supposedly perfect ideal of a white picket fence, a little house, and a nuclear family. For many, the suburban life is the American dream. For others, however, it can turn into a twisted nightmare of unfulfilled desires, repressed needs, and **** hopes. Because of the necessity to keep up appearances, a serene facade often conceals a breeding ground for dysfunction, anxiety, and hypocrisy. Directors like David Lynch have made this their playground. Lynch in particular delights in depicting the root causes of social decay in suburbia - and he does it by autopsy. American Beauty is not as dark as a Lynch project, since it allows for small moments of redemption, but it mines the same general territory.

American Beauty is about the ways in which these characters grow, and the catalysts that break them out of their near-catatonic existences. It's also about the emotional paralysis that comes with age and security. We take refuge in routine, and, after a number of years, the thought of change becomes terrifying. Happiness, the goal of youth, is replaced by the desire for the artificial comfort that comes through the numbing sameness of repetition. Loveless marriages like Lester and Carolyn's exist because neither partner possesses the willingness to break the cycle. And the children they think they're protecting by staying together are often the biggest victims of their sham.

American Beauty is the first feature film directed by Sam Mendes, who has an extensive background in theater, but displays a sureness that many veteran filmmakers are unable to match. At times evoking elements of Todd Solondz' controversial Happiness and Ang Lee's brilliant The Ice Storm, American Beauty weds compelling drama with black comedy. The movie is character-driven, but the three protagonists are so expertly developed that we are drawn to them for the entire two hour running time. Spacey, Bening, and Birch all give the kinds of top-notch performances that deserve (but do not always get) consideration at Oscar time. Spacey's Lester may be American Beauty's narrator, but, through a low-key portrayal that conveys all the angst and confusion of a particularly bad teenage experience, Birch makes Jane the film's emotional focal point.

If there's a weakness in American Beauty, it's in the way the story is structured. Spacey's voiceover narrative effectively kills a great deal of narrative tension when, during an opening scene, he reveals the film's ending. This approach is often forgivable if there's a compelling dramatic reason for it, but that isn't the case here. In fact, the use of the voiceover allows American Beauty to close with more exposition than is necessary. We don't need to be told, for example, that one of the film's points is that we should learn to savor every moment of life and to see all the hidden beauty the world has to offer.

endes and cinematographer Conrad L. Hall add some wonderful camera work, especially when it comes to close-ups. In most films, we rarely notice this kind of shot because it is used indiscriminately. However, in American Beauty, it serves the definite purpose of offering insight into a character's mindset. There are many close-ups in this film, and few (if any) are used for the banal purpose of varying shot selection. And Thomas Newman's dynamic, playful score compliments the picture's effective visual composition.

American Beauty doesn't trailblaze a path into hitherto untouched cinematic territory, but its presentation of vivid characters in interesting situations makes the story seem fresh. In part because it's not a complete downer and in part because it doesn't cheat the audience, American Beauty is emotionally satisfying. There's a sense of poignancy at the end, but also the feeling that we have been on an incredible trip through the lives and souls of three perfectly-realized characters. In a year that boasts few truly memorable motion pictures, Mendes can stake a claim alongside the likes of Kubrick and Egoyan as one whose cinematic vision both challenges and entertains.

A wonderful film that changed the way I looked at movies. "American Beauty" is smart, funny, unexpected and insightful. Wonderful performances, eerie soundtrack, amazing script and a compelling storytelling that turns the ordinary into something special. Look Closer.

I recently just revisited this movie, and I thought I just had to share my opinion. 'American Beauty' is a comedy-drama film directed by British director Sam Mendes in his directorial debut. Since then, he won an Oscar and went on to direct 'Road to Perdition' (2002) and 'Skyfall' (2012).

The movie focuses on a man named Lester (Kevin Spacey), who is going through an intense mid-life crisis. His materialistic wife Carolyn (Annette Benning), ignores him and treats objects like people and people like objects. His 16 year old daughter Jane (Thora Birch) is insecure and is saving up to get her breasts done, she also blames her insecurity on her parents.

Also, Lester's job is hanging on a thread, he feels as if he is unwanted and does not want to continue to work there.

The family also have new next door neighbors moving in, Colonel Frank Fitts (Chris Cooper) with his wife and son, Ricky Fitts (Wes Bentley).

One night, Lester reluctantly joins his wife to go see their daughter perform a cheer-leading routine at her high school. It's there that Lester sees something he truly desires, her name is Angela (Mena Suvari). Angela is a good friend of Jane's ironically, and Lester starts to imagine this young girl in many sexual scenarios. Who can blame him? He hasn't been intimate with his wife for god knows how long, and Angela's features including; blonde hair, blue eyes, and red lips are enough for Lester to lust over this young girl. Is it wrong for a man in his 40s to lust over a teenage girl who has no idea about his dirty fantasies? As long as he doesn't act upon it, then he isn't doing something illegal, but morally, it is wrong.

Meanwhile, Ricky seems to have a sort of fascination for Lester's daughter, Jane. Her natural looks and constant belief that she isn't beautiful makes him more attracted and obsessed with her.

Lester decides to change his life around, bossing around his wife and smoking pot and even bulking up to impress the young Angela. Angela, drugs and quitting his dead-end job are the solutions to ending his mid-life crisis.

'American Beauty' is a beautifully filmed picture, with gorgeous cinematography by the late Conrad L. Hall and sure-handed direction from then-first time director Sam Mendes is astonishing and it's no wonder why he won an Oscar for this.

The second half of this movie does get a little slow-paced, and it does drag. But this movie was a very warped experience with all of the emotional disconnection, and I was still gripped. This is one of the best movies of the 1990s, along with 'Schindler's List' (1993) and 'Goodfellas' (1990).

Over the years, many films have taken a dark look at the supposedly perfect ideal of a white picket fence, a little house, and a nuclear family. For many, the suburban life is the American dream. For others, however, it can turn into a twisted nightmare of unfulfilled desires, repressed needs, and **** hopes. Because of the necessity to keep up appearances, a serene facade often conceals a breeding ground for dysfunction, anxiety, and hypocrisy. Directors like David Lynch have made this their playground. Lynch in particular delights in depicting the root causes of social decay in suburbia - and he does it by autopsy. American Beauty is not as dark as a Lynch project, since it allows for small moments of redemption, but it mines the same general territory.

If there's a rule in American cinema that all families not named Brady must be dysfunctional, then American Beauty does nothing to violate it. Most teenagers think their parents are strange, but, in the case of Jane Burnham (Thora Birch, whose largest previous big screen role was in Alaska), this is as much a state of reality as it is a state of mind. Her father, Lester (Kevin Spacey), is suffering through a mid-life crisis. At the age of 42, he has become apathetic to everything. "Both my wife and daughter think I'm this gigantic loser," he confesses at one point, "And they're right. I have lost something. I didn't always feel this sedated." Meanwhile, Jane's mother, Carolyn (Annette Bening), places such value on status that she has turned into a "bloodless, money-grubbing freak" who has no time for any form of intimacy. Her creed: "You cannot count on anyone except yourself." She and Lester continue in their dead marriage for their daughter's sake and so they'll look normal to the outside world. In a moment of clarity, Lester admits, "Our marriage is just for show - a commercial for how normal we are, when we're anything but."

American Beauty is the first feature film directed by Sam Mendes, who has an extensive background in theater, but displays a sureness that many veteran filmmakers are unable to match. At times evoking elements of Todd Solondz' controversial Happiness and Ang Lee's brilliant The Ice Storm, American Beauty weds compelling drama with black comedy. We don't need to be told, for example, that one of the film's points is that we should learn to savor every moment of life and to see all the hidden beauty the world has to offer.

Mendes and cinematographer Conrad L. Hall add some wonderful camera work, especially when it comes to close-ups. In most films, we rarely notice this kind of shot because it is used indiscriminately. However, in American Beauty, it serves the definite purpose of offering insight into a character's mindset. There are many close-ups in this film, and few (if any) are used for the banal purpose of varying shot selection. And Thomas Newman's dynamic, playful score compliments the picture's effective visual composition.
